descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Stephon Marbury had 20 points, 10 assists and seven rebounds and Jake Tsakalidis matched his career-high with 17 points as the Phoenix Suns beat the Golden State Warriors 104-98 Friday night.

related.description: Marc Jackson wants to be traded to Phoenix, but Suns president Bryan Colangelo said Friday night that the Golden State Warriors rejected his team's final offer.
related.linkText: Suns say Warriors nix deal involving Marc Jackson
related.title: Jackson calls Warriors 'spoiled children'
related.headline: Jackson calls Warriors 'spoiled children'

article.headline: Suns send Warriors to yet another defeat
article.linkText: Marbury dazzles as Suns add to Warriors' misery
article.story:
PHOENIX (AP) -- If Jake Tsakalidis and Alton Ford played every game the way they did Friday night, the Phoenix Suns wouldn't be shopping for another big man. Tsakalidis matched his career high with 17 points and Ford, a rookie, had eight points and 10 rebounds -- twice as many as he'd had in an NBA game -- as the Suns beat the Golden State Warriors 104-98. Before the game, Suns president Bryan Colangelo said the Warriors had turned down his team's final offer for center Marc Jackson. While Phoenix's need for inside muscle remains acute, for one night it wasn't a problem. "We got a contribution from two guys who haven't played that much lately," Suns coach Scott Skiles said. "Big Jake and Alton were a big factor. Both of them gave us a big lift." Stephon Marbury had 20 points, 10 assists and seven rebounds for the Suns. Tsakalidis, starting in place of injured Jake Voskuhl, scored nine in the first quarter as the Suns took a 30-20 lead and never trailed again. Ford was especially effective late in the game as Phoenix handed the Warriors their 13th loss in 15 games and their seventh in a row on the road. "It felt pretty good out there," Ford said, "getting your number called and just taking advantage of it. That's all it is, just going out there and playing hard." Shawn Marion had 17 points and 12 rebounds for the Suns. Antawn Jamison scored 26 and Jason Richardson 22 for Golden State, which cut its deficit to two in the fourth quarter. Larry Hughes added 15 points and 10 assists. Six Suns scored in double figures, including all five starters. Bo Outlaw scored 13. Penny Hardaway scored 10 but committed eight turnovers and didn't play in the fourth quarter. Tsakalidis, who had only three rebounds, also sat out the fourth as the Suns went with a small lineup. Marbury was just 5-for-18 from the field but made 10 of 14 free throws, including six in the fourth quarter. After trailing by as many as 16 in the second half, Golden State cut the lead to 89-87 on Hughes' three-point play with 4:25 to play and was down 91-89 after Danny Fortson's 18-footer with 3:51 remaining. Marion sank a 17-footer, then Tony Delk scored on a drive through traffic to make it 95-89 with 2:37 to go. Golden State never got closer than four the rest of the way. Falling behind and then almost coming back is a familiar theme for the Warriors. "We get it close and just can't seem to get over the hump," Golden State coach Brian Winters said. "But we worked right to the end. What can I say? I sound like a broken record." Jamison said the scenario is getting old. "It's been our story all year," he said. "It's very frustrating. We are a better team than what our record shows right now." Phoenix led by as many as 15 points in the first half and was up 56-44 at the break. The second of Rodney Rogers' two second-quarter 3-pointers put Phoenix up 42-27 with 7:03 to play in the half. Tsakalidis made two free throws, then stuffed one on a lob from Marbury to give Phoenix its biggest lead, 66-50, with 8:35 left in the third quarter. The Warriors rallied with a 13-3 run to cut it to 69-63 on Richardson's 3-pointer with 4:27 to play in the third. Marbury made two free throws, then made a 10-foot floater in the lane to ignite an 8-0 run to make it 77-63. Phoenix led 77-65 entering the fourth quarter

Game notes
Jackson didn't play for the ninth consecutive game. ... Phoenix center Jake Voskuhl sat out the game with a sore foot. ... The teams meet again Sunday night in Oakland. ... It was Dan Majerle "bobblehead" doll night at America West Arena.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
